Award.AwardTitle: ABI Innovation: Integrated Approach to Improve Detection of Genome Rearrangements
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will support the development of an algorithm for finding genome rearrangements from data produced by the next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies. NGS has become an essential tool for the life science research. These technologies are used to address many fundamental questions in various fields of biology allowing one to find exact differences between samples (for instance, related species) via comparison to a reference genome. While single-nucleotide mismatches are robustly identified in such studies, precise and reliable detection of more complex changes, genome rearrangements, still presents a significant problem and solving this problem will benefit a large number of biological researchers. The expected deluge of available genome sequences in the near future will require novel approaches for automated functional predictions dealing with "big data" on a scale unimaginable today. Reliable identification of rearrangements will be an important step in such automated genome annotation. Active involvement and a strong interaction of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral-level participants on Rutgers-Camden campus is foreseen (including members of underrepresented minority groups) in these research activities. All of this work will have a strong synergy with the NSF award supporting the high-performance computational facilities on campus.

With this award, a novel approach for finding genome rearrangements will be developed, based on integrating multiple lines of evidence and logical constraints on mapped paired reads. It will evaluate for each nucleotide in a reference sequence a likelihood of involvement in a rearrangement event. Given the rapidly changing filed of NGS the methodology will also allow for including of novel types of evidence, for example, long reads, to improve predictions of rearrangements. As a result of this research a functional algorithm will be implemented with a user interface, displaying complex rearrangements and highlighting available evidence from the sequence data in a convenient graphical form, together with genomic context information. The algorithm will be described in publications and at scientific meetings and will be made publicly available. This will aid in interpretation of evolutionary, functional and other roles of the detected genomic changes and result in substantial improvements in NGS data analysis in many areas of biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of human genome sequencing (and that of other organisms) is to identify variants that may be responsible for phenotypic differences, diseases and other features in sequenced individuals. Such variant identification is often difficult due to the noise in the sequencing data and the inherent difficulty in finding structural variants, which include deletions, insertions, inversions and translocations of DNA segments. This proposal has focused on developing GROM, a computational tool for fast and reliable detection of genome variants from sequencing data. GROM includes a novel algorithm for variant identification and data visualization tools aiming to simplify structural variant display for manual inspection and annotation of the results.

GROM development has been very successful, resulting in improved precision of variant detection and up to 70 times speed gain compared to standard variant finders. These improvements have led to a US patent application and an ongoing effort (supported by another NSF grant, IIP-1836499) to investigate a potential market for a commercial version of the software. GROM and its applications have been described in several open-access publications, including the analysis of 3,000 rice varieties (in collaboration with several US universities and the International Rice Genome Institute) and genome comparisons of woolly mammoths and elephants. Such comparative analyses using GROM have also led to observations of non-coding RNA genes and RNAses being frequently affected by these variants, which has resonated synergistically with another research direction of the PI: regulatory small RNAs.

The project has involved one postdoctoral researcher and at varying levels of participation over the funding period a total of 15 graduate and undergraduate students (including underrepresented groups) at a small urban campus of Rutgers-Camden, giving them the opportunity to participate in the cutting-edge computational research and algorithm development from the very beginning of their scientific career. Some of them received additional support or awards from Rutgers University for their work with the PI on this project, including a Fellowship for Excellence in Computation and Data Science, Dean's undergraduate research grants, Dean's undergraduate research prizes, dissertation support grants. They have co-authored research papers and posters, presented at research retreats and local, national and international conferences. All of the participants who graduated from the laboratory of the PI have either found research-related jobs in academe and industry or continued their education in medical or graduate schools.
